node.title: For One Rockaways Couple, Lockdown Was a Creative Windfall
node.alt: Playfulness and creativity have been part of Emma Hastil and Daniel Kingâ€™s relationship since the day they met in the apartment they now share in Rockaway Beach, Queens.
node.description: While many hoped to use the enforced isolation of quarantine creatively, the couple who started Locus of Occult actually did.
node.content: ["A box holding silicone in Emma Hastil and Daniel King\u2019s home office carries a slogan that could be the couple\u2019s motto. \u201cWhat are you waiting for?\u201d the cardboard box asks. \u201cMake it now!\u201d", "The silicone lives on a shelving unit packed with supplies \u2014 lint roller, wood paint, primer, eyedroppers, sandpaper \u2014 for the couple\u2019s many creative endeavors. Amid the pandemic, they started an apparel and housewares company called Locus of Occult, which they run out of their two-bedroom apartment in Rockaway Beach, Queens. Below the crowded shelves sit stacks of white T-shirts and five-gallon paint buckets full of Jesmonite, a composite resin they use to make trippy lamps and Memphis-inspired terrazzo bookends.", "Playfulness and creativity have been part of Ms. Hastil and Mr. King\u2019s relationship since the day they met in this apartment.", "One afternoon in the summer of 2019, Ms. Hastil, now 30, was at a nearby beach with a friend, and feeling down. \u201cLet\u2019s go to Dan\u2019s apartment,\u201d she remembered her friend saying. \u201cHe\u2019ll make you feel better.\u201d", "The three of them spent the rest of the day riding bikes along the boardwalk, dancing on Mr. King\u2019s roof to Michael Jackson and disco, and going skinny-dipping under the cover of night until the Parks Department caught them.", "Occupations: Ms. Hastil is a clothing designer; Mr. King is a photographer. They own an apparel and housewares brand.Their favorite place to buy silicone: \u201cThere\u2019s a theater warehouse on Long Island called Silicone & Epoxy Technology, and they gave us tips on what kind of silicones we could use,\u201d she said. \u201cThey supply fake blood and spray foam for all the D.I.Y. horror filmmakers on Long Island.\u201dCollaborating with the neighbors: Mr. King worked on a photo project with Gambino Prince, a local rapper: \u201cI was just walking through the shops with a camera, and he came up and said, \u2018Do you want to shoot my music video?\u2019\u201d", "The pair didn\u2019t exchange numbers that night. They had both recently ended relationships, and their mutual friends warned them, Ms. Hastil said with a laugh, to \u201cstay away from each other,\u201d worried it was too soon for both of them.", "But in October, she finally reached out, and the two began spending time together \u2014 and falling in love \u2014 in the Rockaways.", "Ms. Hastil, a clothing designer, has loved the Rockaways since she moved to New York City in 2009. And as her relationship with Mr. King deepened, so did her relationship with the beach. \u201cAfter moving here, I became part of the community and understood more of what is out here,\u201d she said. \u201cNot just the beach in the summertime, but the off-season, and the community that stays year-round.\u201d", "That community was part of what first drew Mr. King, a photographer who grew up in Sydney, Australia, after a decade of living on the Lower East Side. He began spending time in the Rockaways thanks to a skateboarding friend who grew up there, and moved to the neighborhood in 2018.", "\u201cIt reminds me of Australia here,\u201d he said. \u201cPeople are brought together by the ocean in the summer, because it\u2019s a shared outdoor space. But that sense of community lasts throughout the winter, whether that\u2019s a bonfire at the beach or a game night.\u201d", "In March of 2020, Mr. King was getting ready to depart for a three-month work trip, and Ms. Hastil planned to be gone for a month after that. So she moved into his apartment to see him as much as possible before the long separation. When the pandemic hit, she stayed, moving out of her 200-square-foot studio in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, in September.", "The couple thrived in lockdown. \u201cIt\u2019s like the honeymoon period,\u201d Mr. King said. \u201cWe played backgammon and cards. We were drawing a lot and dancing during the day. What grounded it was being able to walk on the beach.\u201d", "Their casual crafting soon became more serious. For months, Ms. Hastil had been looking at sculptures made from Jesmonite, a material sold in England that creates a stone-like ceramic finish when cast. To make the astronomical shipping costs worthwhile, she ordered 77 pounds of it.", "\u201cYou want to have enough material to do something after the first three failures,\u201d she said. \u201cOtherwise you\u2019ll lose motivation.\u201d", "Soon they were making bookends, incense burners and clocks that looked like an astral projection of the Cogsworth character from \u201cBeauty and the Beast.\u201d They make many of their molds from cardboard, and sand each piece by hand in the kitchen sink.", "You can now find Locus of Occult\u2019s goods in a number of countries, including Australia and Japan. They also fill Ms. Hastil and Mr. King\u2019s apartment, along with other D.I.Y. projects and found art.", "In their living room, an early lamp prototype resembling a Technicolor cairn sits atop a small table that the couple made by covering an olive-oil box with small black-and-white tiles. Across the room is a large plastic slice of pink-frosted cake that Mr. Hastil found on the street. Nearby is a candy corn-orange wood chair that the couple made in the office. A few large prints of Mr. King\u2019s photos, some made for the Australian Wildlife Conservancy, hang on the walls.", "Mr. King and Ms. Hastil have proved themselves expert at finding opportunities for creativity in the droll nooks and crannies of life. They have turned lockdown into an art project, trash into art, a foam box into a papier-m\u00e2ch\u00e9 table painted in squiggles.", "In this apartment, even industrial tools double as design objects, like the drill press that sits in the middle of their office. For a while, it lived in the dining room, but not because of space constraints. \u201cI liked its bright color,\u201d Ms. Hastil said, with a shrug."]
